title: INTERSPEECH_2008_20_abs

sentences.text: In the study of expressive speech communication , it is commonly accepted that the emotion perceived by the listener is a good approximation of the intended emotion conveyed by the speaker .
This paper analyzes the validity of this assumption by comparing the mismatches between the assessments made by na ¨ ıve listeners and by the speakers that generated the data .
The analysis is based on the hypothesis that people are better decoders of their own emotions .
Therefore , self-assessments will be closer to the intended emotions .
Using the IEMOCAP database , discrete -LRB- categorical -RRB- and continuous -LRB- attribute -RRB- emotional assessments evaluated by the actors and na ¨ ıve listeners are compared .
The results indicate that there is a mismatch between the expression and perception of emotion .
The speakers in the database assigned their own emotions to more specific emotional categories , which led to more extreme values in the activation-valence space .

Entity-this_paper.label: This paper
Entity-this_paper.description: This paper presents a research study that investigates the discrepancies between the emotional assessments of naive listeners and the self-assessments of speakers, using the IEMOCAP database to analyze the accuracy of perceived versus intended emotions in expressive speech communication.

Entity-the_speaker_in_the_database.label: The speakers in the database
Entity-the_speaker_in_the_database.description: The speakers in the database refer to the actors from the IEMOCAP database who provided emotional assessments of their own performances in the context of expressive speech communication.

Entity-mismatch.label: mismatches
Entity-mismatch.description: The term 'mismatches' refers to the discrepancies identified between the emotional assessments made by naive listeners and the self-assessments of the speakers in the context of expressive speech communication.

Entity-data.label: data
Entity-data.description: The term 'data' refers to the emotional assessments generated by speakers in the IEMOCAP database, which are analyzed in the context of expressive speech communication.

Entity-iemocap.label: IEMOCAP
Entity-iemocap.description: IEMOCAP is a dataset designed for the study of emotional expression in speech, containing recordings of actors performing scripted dialogues with various emotional tones.

Entity-actor.label: actors
Entity-actor.description: In this paper, 'actors' refers to the individuals who performed and provided emotional assessments in the IEMOCAP database, serving as speakers in the study of expressive speech communication.

Entity-a_mismatch_between_the_expression.label: a mismatch between the expression and perception of emotion
aliases: a mismatch between the expression and perception of emotion
Entity-a_mismatch_between_the_expression.description: A mismatch between the expression and perception of emotion refers to the discrepancy that occurs when the emotional signals conveyed by a speaker do not align with the emotional interpretations made by listeners, suggesting that individuals may have a more accurate understanding of their own emotional states than external observers.

mentions.local_name: a mismatch between the expression and perception of emotion

Entity-decoder.label: decoders
Entity-decoder.description: In the context of expressive speech communication, 'decoders' refers to individuals who interpret and assess their own emotional expressions, suggesting that they have a more accurate understanding of their emotions compared to external observers.

Entity-emotional_assessment.label: emotional assessments
Entity-emotional_assessment.description: Emotional assessments refer to the evaluations of emotions, which can be discrete (categorical) or continuous (attribute-based), conducted by both actors and naive listeners to analyze the accuracy of perceived versus intended emotions in expressive speech communication.

Entity-the_emotion_perceived_by_the_list.label: the emotion perceived by the listener
aliases: the emotion perceived by the listener
Entity-the_emotion_perceived_by_the_list.description: The emotion perceived by the listener refers to the emotional response or interpretation that an audience member derives from a speaker's expressive communication, which is often considered to reflect the speaker's intended emotional message.

mentions.local_name: the emotion perceived by the listener

Entity-assumption.label: assumption
Entity-assumption.description: The 'assumption' refers to the widely accepted belief that the emotion perceived by a listener accurately reflects the intended emotion expressed by a speaker in expressive speech communication.

Entity-more_specific_emotional_category.label: more specific emotional categories
Entity-more_specific_emotional_category.description: More specific emotional categories refer to distinct classifications of emotions that allow for a finer differentiation of emotional experiences, as utilized by speakers in the IEMOCAP database to convey their feelings more accurately.

Entity-discrete_-lrb-_categorical_-rrb-_.label: discrete -LRB- categorical -RRB- and continuous -LRB- attribute -RRB- emotional assessments
aliases: discrete -LRB- categorical -RRB- and continuous -LRB- attribute -RRB- emotional assessments
Entity-discrete_-lrb-_categorical_-rrb-_.description: Discrete (categorical) and continuous attribute emotional assessments refer to the methods of evaluating emotions where discrete assessments categorize emotions into specific groups, while continuous assessments measure emotions along a spectrum, both of which are analyzed in the context of expressive speech communication.

mentions.local_name: discrete -LRB- categorical -RRB- and continuous -LRB- attribute -RRB- emotional assessments

Entity-the_intended_emotion.label: the intended emotions
Entity-the_intended_emotion.description: The intended emotions refer to the specific emotional states that a speaker aims to convey through their expressive speech, which are hypothesized to be more accurately recognized by the speaker themselves than by external listeners.

Entity-assessment.label: assessments
Entity-assessment.description: The term 'assessments' refers to the evaluations of emotional expressions made by both naive listeners and the speakers themselves, focusing on the discrepancies between their perceptions and intended emotions.

Entity-emotional_category.label: emotional categories
Entity-emotional_category.description: Emotional categories refer to the specific classifications of emotions that speakers assign to their own feelings, which are analyzed in the context of expressive speech communication to understand the discrepancies between self-assessment and listener perception.

Entity-na__ve_listener.label: na ¨ ıve listeners
Entity-na__ve_listener.description: Naïve listeners refer to individuals who assess emotional expressions in speech without prior training or expertise, serving as a comparison group to evaluate the accuracy of emotional perception against self-assessments made by the speakers themselves.

Entity-speaker.label: speaker
aliases: the speakers that generated the data
Entity-speaker.description: The term 'speaker' refers to the individuals who generate expressive speech data in the study, specifically those who convey emotions and assess their own emotional expressions in the context of the research.

mentions.local_name: the speakers that generated the data

Entity-expression.label: expression
Entity-expression.description: The term 'expression' refers to the conveyance of emotions through speech, highlighting the discrepancies between how speakers intend to communicate their emotions and how those emotions are perceived by listeners.

Entity-expressive_speech_communication.label: expressive speech communication
aliases: the study of expressive speech communication
Entity-expressive_speech_communication.description: Expressive speech communication refers to the study of how emotions are conveyed through speech and perceived by listeners, focusing on the relationship between the speaker's intended emotions and the listener's interpretations.

mentions.local_name: the study of expressive speech communication

Entity-the_expression_and_perception_of_.label: the expression and perception of emotion
aliases: the expression and perception of emotion
Entity-the_expression_and_perception_of_.description: The expression and perception of emotion refers to the processes by which individuals convey their emotional states through expressive behaviors and how these emotions are interpreted or understood by others, highlighting the potential discrepancies between the intended emotional message of the speaker and the emotional response of the listener.

mentions.local_name: the expression and perception of emotion

Entity-the_intended_emotion_conveyed_by_.label: the intended emotion conveyed by the speaker
aliases: the intended emotion conveyed by the speaker
Entity-the_intended_emotion_conveyed_by_.description: The intended emotion conveyed by the speaker refers to the specific emotional state or feeling that the speaker aims to express through their speech, which may differ from how listeners perceive that emotion.

mentions.local_name: the intended emotion conveyed by the speaker

Entity-the_hypothesis_that_people_are_be.label: the hypothesis that people are better decoders of their own emotions
aliases: the hypothesis that people are better decoders of their own emotions
Entity-the_hypothesis_that_people_are_be.description: The hypothesis that individuals possess a superior ability to accurately interpret and understand their own emotional states compared to external observers.

mentions.local_name: the hypothesis that people are better decoders of their own emotions

Entity-their_own_emotion.label: their own emotions
Entity-their_own_emotion.description: The phrase 'their own emotions' refers to the personal emotional experiences and feelings that individuals are able to recognize and assess more accurately than external observers.

Entity-perception.label: perception
Entity-perception.description: In this context, 'perception' refers to the listener's interpretation and understanding of the emotions expressed by a speaker, highlighting the discrepancies between what is conveyed and what is understood.

Entity-analysis.label: analysis
Entity-analysis.description: The analysis refers to the examination of the hypothesis that individuals are more accurate in interpreting their own emotional expressions compared to those perceived by others.

Entity-more_extreme_value.label: more extreme values
Entity-more_extreme_value.description: The term 'more extreme values' refers to the heightened emotional intensity levels assigned by speakers to specific emotional categories within the activation-valence space, indicating a greater divergence in emotional expression compared to listener perceptions.

Entity-more_extreme_value_in_the_activat.label: more extreme values in the activation-valence space
aliases: more extreme values in the activation-valence space
Entity-more_extreme_value_in_the_activat.description: The phrase 'more extreme values in the activation-valence space' refers to the heightened emotional intensity and specificity assigned by speakers to their emotions, as measured within a framework that categorizes emotions based on their activation (energy level) and valence (pleasantness or unpleasantness).

mentions.local_name: more extreme values in the activation-valence space

Entity-listener.label: listener
Entity-listener.description: The 'listener' refers to an individual or participant who perceives and interprets the emotional content of speech, particularly in the context of expressive communication.

Entity-people.label: people
Entity-people.description: In this context, 'people' refers to individuals who are capable of interpreting and understanding their own emotional states, specifically in relation to expressive speech communication.

Entity-activation-valence_space.label: activation-valence space
Entity-activation-valence_space.description: The activation-valence space is a psychological and emotional model that represents emotions based on two dimensions: activation (the level of arousal) and valence (the intrinsic attractiveness or averseness of an emotion), used to analyze the relationship between expressed and perceived emotions in expressive speech communication.

Entity-self-assessments.label: self-assessments
Entity-self-assessments.description: Self-assessments are tools or methods used by individuals to evaluate their own thoughts, feelings, or behaviors, often aimed at gaining insight into their psychological state.

Entity-emotion.label: emotion
Entity-emotion.description: Emotion refers to a complex psychological state that involves a subjective experience, a physiological response, and a behavioral or expressive response, often categorized as affective states.

Entity-database.label: database
Entity-database.description: A database is a structured collection of data that is stored and accessed electronically, typically managed by a database management system, allowing for efficient data retrieval, manipulation, and organization.

Entity-result.label: results
Entity-result.description: Results refer to the findings or outcomes derived from a study or analysis.

Entity-hypothesis.label: hypothesis
Entity-hypothesis.description: A hypothesis is a proposed explanation or theory that can be tested through research and experimentation.

Entity-paper.label: paper
Entity-paper.description: A paper is a written document that presents research findings, analyses, or arguments, typically in an academic or scholarly context.

summary: In the study of expressive speech communication , it is commonly accepted that the emotion perceived by the listener is a good approximation of the intended emotion conveyed by the speaker . This paper analyzes the validity of this assumption by comparing the mismatches between the assessments made by na ¨ ıve listeners and by the speakers that generated the data . The analysis is based on the hypothesis that people are better decoders of their own emotions . Therefore , self-assessments will be closer to the intended emotions . Using the IEMOCAP database , discrete -LRB- categorical -RRB- and continuous -LRB- attribute -RRB- emotional assessments evaluated by the actors and na ¨ ıve listeners are compared . The results indicate that there is a mismatch between the expression and perception of emotion . The speakers in the database assigned their own emotions to more specific emotional categories , which led to more extreme values in the activation-valence space .

Predicate-is_a_good_approximation_of.label: is a good approximation of
Predicate-is_a_good_approximation_of.description: The predicate 'is a good approximation of' indicates a relationship where the subject represents a close or reasonable representation of the object, suggesting that while there may be differences, the subject captures the essential qualities or characteristics of the object effectively enough to be considered similar or comparable.

Predicate-analyzes.label: analyzes
Predicate-analyzes.description: The predicate 'analyzes' indicates an action where the subject conducts a detailed examination or study of the object, which is typically a concept, idea, or data set. This action involves breaking down the object into its components to understand its structure, meaning, or implications.

Predicate-is_compared_by.label: is compared by
Predicate-is_compared_by.description: The predicate 'is compared by' indicates a relationship where the subject is evaluated or assessed in relation to the object. This suggests that the subject is being analyzed or measured against the criteria, characteristics, or standards represented by the object, highlighting similarities, differences, or discrepancies between them.

Predicate-are_made_by.label: are made by
Predicate-are_made_by.description: The predicate 'are made by' indicates a relationship where the subject is the result or product of an action performed by the object. It signifies that the object is the agent or creator responsible for the existence or formation of the subject.

Predicate-is_based_on.label: is based on
Predicate-is_based_on.description: The predicate 'is based on' establishes a foundational relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject derives its principles, conclusions, or framework from the object. It suggests that the subject's validity, reasoning, or structure is contingent upon the object, which serves as a source of support, justification, or inspiration.

Predicate-involves.label: involves
Predicate-involves.description: The predicate 'involves' indicates a relationship where the subject encompasses or requires the presence or participation of the object as a necessary component or element. It suggests that the subject cannot be fully understood or realized without considering the object, highlighting a connection or interaction between the two.

Predicate-are.label: are
Predicate-are.description: The predicate 'are' serves as a linking verb that connects the subject to the complement, indicating a state of being or identity. It establishes a relationship where the subject is defined or characterized by the object, suggesting that the subject possesses the qualities or attributes described by the object.

Predicate-decode.label: decode
Predicate-decode.description: The predicate 'decode' signifies the process by which the subject interprets, analyzes, or makes sense of the object, often involving the transformation of complex or unclear information into a more understandable form. In this context, it implies that the subject engages in cognitive or emotional processing to clarify or reveal the meaning of the object.

Predicate-will_be_closer_to.label: will be closer to
Predicate-will_be_closer_to.description: The predicate 'will be closer to' indicates a future state of proximity or alignment between the subject and the object. It suggests that the subject is expected to approach or approximate the qualities, characteristics, or values represented by the object over time. This implies a process of change or development where the subject's attributes or perceptions are anticipated to become more similar or aligned with those of the object.

Predicate-compares.label: compares
Predicate-compares.description: The predicate 'compares' indicates a relationship in which the subject evaluates or analyzes the similarities and/or differences between itself and the object. This involves assessing various attributes, characteristics, or qualities to establish a relationship of equivalence, contrast, or distinction.

Predicate-evaluated_by.label: evaluated by
Predicate-evaluated_by.description: The predicate 'evaluated by' indicates a relationship where the subject is subjected to an assessment or judgment performed by the object. It signifies that the object, typically a person or group, is responsible for analyzing, interpreting, or providing feedback on the subject, thereby establishing a dynamic of evaluation and appraisal.

Predicate-indicate.label: indicate
Predicate-indicate.description: The predicate 'indicate' serves to establish a relationship where the subject provides evidence or signals that point towards the existence or nature of the object. It suggests that the subject reveals, suggests, or demonstrates something specific about the object, often implying a connection or correlation between the two.

Predicate-is_between.label: is between
Predicate-is_between.description: The predicate 'is between' indicates a relational position or state where the subject exists in a mediating or intermediary role concerning the object. It suggests that the subject serves as a link or connection that exists in the space or context defined by the object, which typically consists of two distinct entities or concepts. This relationship implies that the subject interacts with, influences, or is situated in relation to the two components represented by the object.

Predicate-assigned.label: assigned
Predicate-assigned.description: The predicate 'assigned' indicates a relationship in which the subject is responsible for designating or allocating a particular quality, state, or feeling represented by the object. In this context, it suggests that the subject has the authority or capability to determine or influence the emotional state of the object, thereby establishing a connection between the two entities.

Predicate-to.label: to
Predicate-to.description: The predicate 'to' serves as a relational connector that indicates a directional or associative link between the subject and the object. In the context of the example triple, it suggests that the subject (emotion) is related to or categorized by the object (emotional categories), implying a movement or transition from the subject to the object in terms of classification or understanding.

Predicate-led_to.label: led to
Predicate-led_to.description: The predicate 'led to' indicates a causal relationship where the subject is a contributing factor or cause that results in the occurrence or existence of the object. It implies that there is a directional influence from the subject to the object, suggesting that changes or developments in the subject bring about specific outcomes or effects represented by the object.

Predicate-are_identified_between.label: are identified between
Predicate-are_identified_between.description: The predicate 'are identified between' indicates a relationship where the subject is recognized or distinguished in relation to the object, suggesting a connection or comparison that highlights the presence or occurrence of the subject within the context defined by the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a more specific instance or category that falls under the wider classification represented by the object. This relationship implies that the object encompasses a larger scope or set of characteristics that includes the subject, thereby situating the subject within a broader conceptual framework.
